title: Cincinnati Enquirer Wins National Edward R. Murrow Award
text:
CLOSE

The Edward R. Murrow Awards are presented by the RTDNA. (Photo: Karen Hansen (RTDNA))

The USA TODAY NETWORK is extremely proud of The Cincinnati Enquirer for being named a winner of the 2018 National Edward R. Murrow Awards earlier this week. The Enquirer was honored for excellence in video for its Seven Days of Heroin project.

The Enquirer’s “Seven Days of Heroin: This is What an Epidemic Looks Like” shines a spotlight on Cincinnati’s opioid and heroin crisis. Over the course of one week, 60 journalists investigated what has become the region’s greatest health crisis, during which they reported 180 overdoses and 18 deaths.

The Radio Television Digital News Association has presented the Edward R. Murrow Awards – one of the most prestigious in journalism – for outstanding achievements in broadcast and digital journalism since 1971. The 2018 National Murrow Awards, which received more than 4,400 entries, honored 118 examples of outstanding journalism in 16 different categories. The recipients came from 89 local and network radio, television and digital news organizations.

“Winning an RTDNA National Edward R. Murrow Award means that a news organization has provided exemplary public service to its viewers, listeners and readers. These honorees truly represent the very best in broadcast and digital journalism around the world,” said Dan Shelley, RTDNA Executive Director.

“Every person who worked on this project was committed to chronicling this horrible epidemic in a meaningful way, and it’s truly amazing to see their hard work recognized with a National Murrow Award,” said Peter Bhatia, who was editor of The Enquirer when the project was done and is now the editor of the Detroit Free Press. “Receiving this honor recognizes the excellence in video at The Enquirer and an extraordinary staff of visual journalists who are making a difference in their work every day.”

Seven Days in Heroin was also recognized nationally earlier this year as a Pulitzer Prize winner for local reporting.
